name: Kepler-384
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-384 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-384 is a star with 0.775 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.88 times its radius. It is located 2998.81 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-384 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-384 b

Kepler-384 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 22.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-384.

The mass of Kepler-384 b is 1.27 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-384 b is 1.12 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-384 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-384 c

Kepler-384 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 45.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-384.

The mass of Kepler-384 c is 1.30 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-384 c is 1.13 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-384 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-384, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
